We are reporting our financial results in accordance with international financial reporting standards or IFRS. As always, we will also discuss non-GAP performance measures, which should be viewed as supplemental. MDNA contains definitions of each one used in our reporting. All of the dollar figures expressed on this call are Canadian unless otherwise known. We're also hosting our annual general meeting this morning, so we hope you'll join us live via the broadcast at eleven AM. I'll now turn it over to Francois to review our Q1 financials and then George will comment on our business and market outlook. Thank you, Kevin, and good morning everyone. I am pleased to share with you the results of our first quarter of fiscal twenty twenty two. Our revenue growth continues to accelerate on a constant currency basis, fueled by strong bookings from prior quarters, along with continued demand for our digital services and business solutions. In addition, we delivered double digit EPS growth despite a strong Canadian dollar causing handwinds in our reporting currency. We recorded revenue of three point one billion dollars up six point eight percent year over year on a constant currency basis. Strong constant currency growth was seen in the following segments Asia Pacific up nineteen point five percent, Western and Southern Europe up fifteen point two percent. US commercial and state government up fourteen point five percent, Central and Eastern Europe up eleven point nine percent, and Canada up eight point three percent. Total bookings were three point six billion dollars, representing a book to bill of one hundred and sixteen point five percent for the quarter and lifting our trailing twelve months book to bill to one hundred and fifteen point two percent compared to one hundred and three percent for the prior year. I would like to call out a few segments with strong bookings in the quarter. Scandinavia at one hundred and seventeen percent. U TheK and Australia at one hundred and twenty two percent. And Finland, Poland and Baltics with a book to bill of three hundred and fifty three percent, driven by a new eight year managed services contract signed with the Finnish government, whereby CGI will serve as the largest provider of hybrid IT services to dozens of public sector organizations. In addition, yesterday we announced an award by the U.S. Department of Justice for a two hundred and fifty million US dollar blanket purchase agreement with the first task order already granted for a value of one hundred and thirty four million US dollars or approximately one hundred and seventy million in Canadian dollars. Out of our eight proximity geographic segments, six now have a trailing twelve months book to bill well above a hundred percent. New business was thirty-three percent of bookings, an increase from the previous year's twenty-eight percent. On a trelling twelve month basis, new business was also thirty-three percent as compared to twenty-six percent for their year-ago period. Our global backlog increased to by eight hundred and eight million dollars year over year and remained strong at twenty three point six billion dollars. This backlog represents one point nine times revenue, the vast majority of which is comprised of long term managed services and digital transformation engagement. Given the continued increase demand for our services, as reflected by the strong bookings in the last few quarters, we expect continuing positive momentum. On the profitability front, adjusted EBIT in T one was five hundred and twenty one point five million dollars while EBIT margins increased to sixteen point nine percent, up fifty basis points compared to Q one last year. The year over year increase was mainly due to revenue growth in IT services and solutions and improved utilization primarily within the Western and Southern Europe, Central and Eastern Europe, and US federal segments. In addition, we continue to benefit from stronger margins due to operational excellence. We delivered strong EBIT margins in the following segments Asia Pacific at thirty two point one percent, Canada at twenty five point six percent, UK and Australia at fifteen point eight percent and Western and southern Europe at fifteen point four percent. Due to the strength of our value proposition to clients and our embedded indexation clauses with our c i w within our contracts, we have largely been able to absorb wage and other cost pressures in our pricing. Our effective tax rate in Q one was twenty five point five percent compared to twenty five point nine percent in the prior year. We continue to expect our tax rate for future quarters to be in the range of twenty four point five to twenty six point five percent. And earnings were three hundred sixty seven million dollars in And diluted earnings per share were one dollar and forty nine cents, representing an increase of twelve point nine percent year over year. This improvement was mainly due to revenue growth and e-bet margins improvements as outlined earlier. Excluding integration costs and earnings were three hundred and sixty nine million dollars for a margin of eleven point nine percent, and diluted earnings per share were one dollar and fifty cents, an accretion of twelve point eight percent when compared to one dollar and thirty three cents in the same quarter last year. In the quarter, cash provided by operating activities were was four hundred e andighty four million dollars compared to five hundred and ninety seven million dollars in the prior year, which had reduced variable compensation payments related to the impact of the pandemic. As a percentage of revenue, our cash generation was strong at 15.7%. The DSO was 45 days compared to 44 days last year aligned with our targets. For the last 12 months, cash provided by operating activities was two billion dollars or sixteen point four percent of revenue. This represents eight dollars and two cents in cash per share. In the quarter, we invested two hundred and six million dollars in our build and buy profitable growth strategy, mainly in our IP and for the acquisition of CONI Case Management Consulting and RA. In addition, we use two hundred sixty seven million dollars to buy back our stock. Buying back CGI stock has been an accretive and flexible way to return capital to shareholders. As such, yesterday, our board of directors approved the extension of the NCIB program until February 2023, allowing us to purchase up to 18.8 million shares over the next 12 months. In addition, we reimburse two hundred and fifty million US dollars of scheduled debt repayments in the quarter, leaving only fifty million US dollars of scheduled debt repayments for the remainder of fiscal twenty twenty two. With the issuance of our senior notes in September twenty twenty one, CGI's weighted average maturity is now four point nine years with a hundred percent fixed interest uh fixed interest rate at very favorable rates. Consistent with previous years, we review our capital allocation plan to formulate the most effective capital deployment strategy to maximize shareholder returns. In Qan, we delivered a return on invested capital of fifteen point three percent, a significant increase when compared to fifth twelve point four percent in the year ago period, returning to pre pandemic levels. Looking ahead, as and as indicated during our investor day this past November, our cash allocation priority remains the same. Investing in our business, pursuing accreditative acquisition and buying back our stock. This is due in part to the expansion of our local consulting practices and the related increased investment in hiring and developing industry expertise. Our next area of investment, technology expertise, helps clients balance the potential of technology with the reality of complex enterprise delivery.
